title: Liberia: Legislature Limits Education Budget to Salaries, Minister Hit
text:
Gambia: President Jammeh Pardons Death Row, Life Convicts From 1994-2013 
The Minister of Education, George Werner failed to appear before the Ways, Means, Finance and Development planning and Public Account and Expenditure committee when he was requested during the budget hearing period but chose to go to the Ministry of Information press briefing to announce the closure of schools. 
The Minister's action was carried out a day after he appeared before the plenary of the House of Representatives to give reason for his decision to close school two months after the country resume regular academic activities after recovering from the Ebola Virus Disease outbreak, a claim the minister denied at the time. Minister Werner is on record for telling Journalists that he goes where his boss sends him after he was asked why he skipped the budget hearing. 
Asked whether the decision to only approve money for personnel cost for the Education Ministry in the budget was the legislature way of getting back at the Minister, Rep. Kollie said: "We don't have a personal problem with the Minister what we are doing is to follow the procedure. He needs to come and tell us what was done with money given him last year and how he intends to use money that have been allocated now." 
Budget passed 
In a related budget new the House of Representatives has voted to pass the 2015/2016 fiscal year National budget at six hundred twenty-two million, seven hundred, forty-three thousand, four hundred and twenty dollars (US$622,743,420.00). In the country original Revenue submission, the core revenue envelope as per FY 15/16 draft budget was USD$604, 040, 520, with additional Revenues at USD 1,876,100 including additional revenue from budget hearing. 
Under additional revenue from the budget hearing the committee said it realized some revenue which includes Tax Revenue, US$9,371,202, non-Tax revenue of USD 1,247,302 and Grant USD 10,000,000. Under additional Brought forward revenue from FY14/15. Under consolidated fund, the committee also realized the amount of US$8, 400,000 with Maritime accounting for US$2,179,000. A total additional revenue USD$8,702,900 and total adjusted core revenue of USD 612,743,420 and a cutting revenue of 10,000,000. 
The draft budget received forty votes in favor of its passage, with two voting against and three abstaining from the process. Some lawmakers prior to the budget passage had complained of not seeing the budget after committee work and had expressed serious reservations over why they should vote for a budget that they themselves have not seen. 
Though there was no increment made in the salary of civil servants Representative Kollie told journalists that there is ten million United States dollars (US$10M) allotted in the final draft of the budget intended to be used for direct district development fund to be distributed among the 73 electoral districts. According to Rep. Kollie, lawmakers will not be receiving the money for projects in their districts but money allotted will go through the Public Procurement and Concession Commission process through a bidding process conducted before projects are carry out by companies vetted by the vetting committees. In 2013 after the nationwide tour on the country's draft petroleum law, lawmakers, specifically members of the lower house returned with an idea of allocating USD 73M as district development funds for the 73 districts around the country. 
The idea proposed by the lawmakers was met with mixed reaction from members of the Public, political analyst. Some in their reaction said the proposal by the lawmakers was untimely because according to them there are many other important things that should be prioritize through budgetary allocations than putting money to support lawmakers projects. Meanwhile the budget has been sent to the Liberian senate for concurrence before it is sent to the President for approval. Liberia
